Samsung GenAI can only be accessed through the browser session; it has no public API, so every test run must piggyback on the cookies stored in the logged-in profile. Follow this quick checklist before trying manual translation flows:

1. Use the same Chrome/Edge profile you used to log in to https://genai.sec.samsung.net. The extension's background worker reuses that profile's cookies via `fetch(..., { credentials: 'include' })`.
2. Visit https://genai.sec.samsung.net/api/account/auth/session in that profile. If it returns `{"statusCode":200}` you must log in again; a `200` plus user metadata means the session is warm and the background translator can call chat endpoints.
3. If you are not logged in, open https://genai.sec.samsung.net (the tab can be closed once the login redirect finishes). The login flow below shows the expected 302/303 hops through Samsung's Keycloak/ADFS stack.
4. Only after the session endpoint returns user info should you trigger Read Frog translations. The provider config intentionally leaves API-key fields blank because Samsung GenAI relies entirely on the browser session.

⚠️ Samsung's session endpoint always returns `{"statusCode":200}`. A **valid** login response also includes a populated `data` object (id, name, email, permissions, etc.). The extension now treats `200` responses without `data` as unauthenticated and will reopen the GenAI tab until a full payload arrives.
